title: Do I qualify for chapter 7 bankruptcy in california?
question: Defaulted on close to 28k worth of debt
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Car loan
answers:
"Qualifying" for a chapter 7 bankruptcy is not really the correct way to describe this, but effectively it's close. Qualifying to file and discharging particular claims are two completely separate issues. What debt is dischargeable? What rights do certain creditors have to your assets as part of a security agreement? What asset might you lose to the court-appointed trustee if you file? If you file individually, what effect does your filing have on your spouse?

These are questions that can only be answered by an experienced bankruptcy attorney and only after a thorough discussion of your particular situation. That discussion goes beyond "net" earnings to subjects such as types of debt you have, changeability of debt, assets, income, events that have occurred over the past several years, such as transfers of assets, payments to creditors or family... This list is long and detailed. Without this detailed consultation and examination of the facts, you can't really know how a bankruptcy will work for you and what the likely result will be.

As you can see, it goes well beyond being able to file, but whether you should file and what it will do for you. See an attorney and get the details!

Given what you have stated, it appears you will qualify for a chapter 7. Also, did you ever file bankruptcy before? And if so, did you receive a discharge? If you received a discharge in a chapter 7 you must wait 8 years before you can receive another chapter 7 bankruptcy discharge. Filing out your schedules and statements accurately the first time is important and gets you through the process much faster. If you can, I would try to speak with a bankruptcy attorney to help you out.

The person you spoke to at the "auto loan place" is there to collect on a auto loan. His job is to convince you to pay the loan, and if he needs to tell you that you won't qualify for bankruptcy to get you to do so, he will. The chances he has any familiarity with bankruptcy qualification are slim to none, its unlikely he is an attorney, much less an bankruptcy attorney.
Most bankruptcy attorneys do not charge for an initial consultation. Set up an appointment and have someone who knows what he/she is doing tell you if you qualify.

Yes..you appear easily able to file. But asking that means you have NOT spoken to a qualified and experienced bankruptcy attorney yet! That is crucial and its free most all places so do it now. All your assets could affect our advice to you. Your income looks fine but sometimes persons leave off other income..Other issues and facts can gravely affect any attorneys advice to you though so I will point out some of them next to make you realize you NEED to meet and discuss with an attorney now in CA near you ..look here on AVVO.
You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an
attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping
everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the
exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523
(Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and
presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so
you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!
Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your
state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but
your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity
thereof!
Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your
options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you
have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply
with your attorney too.
But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a
relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that
relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the
bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so
meet with one no matter what.
Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one
as soon as you can.
You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now
and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

Chapter 7 is the most common type of bankruptcy. Qualifying for chapter 7 involves several tests (income/expenses, assets) and requires an attorney to review your situation in detail. That said, you appear to be a candidate for chapter 7. Do not take legal advice from the car loan place.
So far so good, but the devil is in the details. Its not a fast food answer....get with an experienced attorney and drill down deeper.

The only way to know for certain is to talk to a qualified bankruptcy attorney. Avvo.com is not a replacement for professional opinion based on a client's individual circumstances. Do not be discouraged by the "auto loan place." Most bankruptcy attorneys offer free consultations. Use the "Find a Lawyer" function on this website. Good luck.
